awd_titl_txt: Nanomanufacturing of High-temperature Superconductor Circuits Using Focused Ion Beams
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective is to investigate high-throughput, large-area nanomanufacturing of high-temperature ceramic oxide superconductor electronics. At liquid nitrogen temperature, ceramic oxide materials superconduct, i.e., they conduct electricity without offering resistance. These superconductors are anisotropic and the conductivity varies in different crystallographic directions, which complicates the manufacturing of Josephson junctions, the building-blocks of these circuits. Recent advances in focused ion beam technology has opened up a new resistless direct-write nanomanufacturing method for high-temperature superconductor electronics that has the potential to improve performance and reduce cost. This research involves several disciplines in science and engineering including nanofabrication, superconductor electronics, and cryogenics. The project will develop knowledge and skills in film growth, nanofabrication, mathematical modeling, advanced low noise electron transport measurement techniques as well as critical thinking to prepare students for careers in Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics. The Institute's Faculty Mentor Program will be utilized to create opportunities for women and underrepresented minority students. The superconductor electronics industry will be impacted in areas from high performance cryogenic computing to high temperature semiconductor amplifiers.

The challenges to fabricating high transition temperature (high-Tc) ceramic oxide superconductor circuits are several. Its anisotropic crystal structure complicates the manufacture of Josephson junctions. The figure of merit for Josephson junctions scales exponentially with the circuit critical dimension. High performance devices require feature sizes in the sub-10 nanometer regime. Variation of even 1 nm can result in large fluctuations in the figure of merit. Despite these challenges many high-Tc junction manufacturing techniques have emerged over the last three decades but none is able to generate large numbers of Josephson junctions with high-yield and predictable properties. This award utilizes a finely focused 0.5 nm helium ion beam to directly modify the superconducting material for the precise fabrication of nanowires for Josephson junctions. The key to this method is that the material is very sensitive to the oxygen ordering in the crystal lattice which can be altered by light ion irradiation. Restricting this altered region to the nanoscale allows for the creation of in-plane tunneling barriers directly in the material with no resists or etching. The method is compatible with commercially available high-TC superconductor films on relatively inexpensive large area sapphire wafers. There are a number of variables in the parameter space for this process, such as beam current, dose, film thickness, and spatial Josephson junction dimensions. The goal is to study the impact of these parameters throughput, yield, and figure of merit uniformity.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the nanomanufacturing aspects of high-transition temperature superconducting Josephson junctions fabricated by direct helium ion beam writing.  In this process, a gas field helium ion source is focused down to a beam with diameter of less than 1nm, and used to irradiate a thin film of superconducting material. When the helium beam interacts with the material it converts those regions to insulator. By precisely controlling the beam, insulating regions can be drawn into the material and define electrical circuits. The resolution of the insulating lines can be of the order of a nanometer which is narrow enough to allow for the creation of in-plane Josephson tunnel junctions.  The goal of our program was to investigate this manufacturing process for development of a reliable manufacturing technology for high temperature superconducting circuits Specific objectives were to:

1.) optimize the focused ion beam parameters and writing technique,

2.) chart the parameter space and capabilities of the devices that can be manufactured,

3.) develop other necessary integrated circuit components and

4.) increase process scalability.

Under objective 1, we have identified procedures to optimize the helium ion beam characteristics for smaller nanofeatures and greater stability.

Beam Energy: Early efforts focused on increasing the helium beam energy to achieve narrower and more concentrated devices. By working with Carl Zeiss engineers, we determined an ion source formation method to allow us to create stable field emission ion sources operating at 40 kV. This is 10 kV higher than what is typically used. This extra energy allows us to implant 20nm deeper into the substrate and create a more uniform junction in the thin film. 

Beam Current: The current of the ion beam plays a key role in determining the electrical properties of the Josephson junctions. We determined accurately knowing this value is essential to reproducibility. With the source focused down and apertured to its smallest diameter, of the order of one nanometer, the typical beam current is only 0.5pA +-0.2pA.  The large fluctuation creates uncertainty in the process. To help remedy this uncertainty a Faraday cup was constructed on the specimen holder near the sample and a third party femto-ammeter was used to read out the current. In this configuration we reduced the fluctuation by a factor of two to 0.1pA.

Beam Astigmatism: The other factor that we identified as crucial to manufacturing uniform devices was careful adjustment of the electrical lenses used to correct beam astigmatism. Procedures were developed to aid in this adjustment which increased circuit yield.

 

Under objective 2, we researched the parameter space of junctions that can be obtained using this process. We accomplished this by studying the following parameters:

Junction Resistance: In our studies we varied the junction width and the ion beam dose to chart out the accessible ranges of resistance. Wide devices of several microns exhibited resistances of about 0.1 Ohms, while much smaller 100nm wide devices exhibited resistances as high as 50 Ohms.  This is a significant result as the value is 10 times larger than previously demonstrated for high-Tc Josephson junctions.  These higher resistance values significantly increase performance of the junctions and reduce noise.

Junction Critical Current: The critical current of the junction is another important parameter. In our work we studied how to maximize it. The main parameters affecting critical current was found to be related to beam focus and astigmatism.  Improved focusing procedures and astigmatism correction techniques allowed us to increase the critical currents of our devices by a factor of 2.

 

3. Under objective 3, we developed additional direct-write components that could be written into the material using the helium ion beam.

Resistors: We successfully patterned direct write resistors with both temperature dependent and independent resistances. With values ranging from fractions of an Ohm to MegaOhms.

Inductors: We successfully fabricated direct-write inductors with values as small as a few pH and as large as 1mH.

Capacitors: Similarly direct write helium ion capacitors were demonstrated with values ranging between pF to uF.

 

4. Under objective 4 we sought to scale up the number of junctions per device and demonstrated large Junction arrays for signal detection consisting of over 2000 junctions for circuit. This is a factor of 100 times larger than previously demonstrated.  In addition, we scaled up the overall size of the area of the substrate that can be used for the process from 100s of microns to millimeters. We accomplished this by developing automatic focusing and alignment routines.

 

Broader Impacts:

Overall this award supported 13 papers, 7 PHD theses, 25 invited talks, 22 graduate student presentations, 3 undergraduate student presentations.

This award has also had a great impact on supporting diverse domestic graduate research education. In part this award supported, and graduated 7 PhD students, of which, includes 4 US Citizens, as well as 4 persons from underrepresented groups. 


Last Modified: 03/15/2022
Modified by: Shane A Cybart

This project investigated the nanomanufacturing aspects of high-transition temperature superconducting Josephson junctions fabricated by direct helium ion beam writing.  In this process, a gas field helium ion source is focused down to a beam with diameter of less than 1nm, and used to irradiate a thin film of superconducting material. This is a factor of 100 times larger than previously demonstrated. We accomplished this by developing automatic focusing and alignment routines.

 

Broader Impacts:

Overall this award supported 13 papers, 7 PHD theses, 25 invited talks, 22 graduate student presentations, 3 undergraduate student presentations.

This award has also had a great impact on supporting diverse domestic graduate research education. In part this award supported, and graduated 7 PhD students, of which, includes 4 US Citizens, as well as 4 persons from underrepresented groups.
